classmethod as_choices(translate=None)¶

Returns members as list of 2-tuples suitable as choices for HTML select lists.

Tuple[0] is the name of the member as string, and tuple[1] is its value.

Parameters:translate – Optional translation function. Assumes, member’s value is a translation string.
Returns:Members as list of 2-tuples

pym.lib.init_cli_locale(locale_name)¶

Initialises CLI locale and encoding.

Sets a certain locale. Ensures that output is correctly encoded, whether it is send directly to a console or piped.

Parameters:locale_name – A locale name, e.g. “de_DE.utf8”.
Returns:active locale as 2-tuple (lang_code, encoding)

pym.lib.normpath(path)¶

Returns normalised version of user defined path.

Normalised means, relative path segments like ‘..’ are resolved and leading ‘..’ are removed. E.g.:

"/../../foo/../../bar"  --> "bar"
"/../../foo/bar"        --> "foo/bar"
"/foo/bar"              --> "foo/bar"
pym.lib.rreplace(s, old, new, occurrence)¶

Replaces the last n occurrences of a thing.

>>> s = '1232425'
'1232425'
>>> rreplace(s, '2', ' ', 2)
'123 4 5'
>>> rreplace(s, '2', ' ', 3)
'1 3 4 5'
>>> rreplace(s, '2', ' ', 4)
'1 3 4 5'
>>> rreplace(s, '2', ' ', 0)
'1232425'

http://stackoverflow.com/a/2556252

Parameters:
  • s – Haystack
  • old – Needle
  • new – Replacement
  • occurrence – How many
Returns:

The resulting string
pym.lib.safepath(path, sep='/')¶

Returns safe version of path.

Safe means, path is normalised with func:normpath, and all parts are sanitised like this:

  • cannot start with dash -
  • cannot start with dot .
  • cannot have control characters: 0x01..0x1F (0..31) and 0x7F (127)
  • cannot contain null byte 0x00
  • cannot start or end with whitespace
  • cannot contain ‘/’, ‘’, ‘:’ (slash, backslash, colon)
  • consecutive whitespace are folded to one blank

See also:

  • http://www.dwheeler.com/essays/fixing-unix-linux-filenames.html
  • http://www.dwheeler.com/secure-programs/Secure-Programs-HOWTO/file-names.html
pym.lib.slugify(s, force_ascii=False, **kw)¶

Converts string into a ‘slug’ for use in URLs.

Since nowadays we can use UTF-8 characters in URLs, we keep those intact, and just replace white space with a dash, except when you force ASCII by setting that parameter.

If you force_ascii, we use python-slugify to convert the string. Additional keyword arguments are passed.

We do not encode unicode in UTF-8 here, since most web frameworks do that transparently themselves.

Parameters:
  • s – The string to slugify.
  • force_ascii – If False (default) we allow unicode chars.
  • **kw –

    Additional keyword arguments are passed to python-slugify.
Returns:

The slug, still a unicode string but maybe just containing ASCII chars.
pym.lib.trim_blanks(s)¶

Removes leading and trailing whitespace from string.

pym.lib.truncate_html_words(s, num, end_text='&hellip;')¶

Truncates HTML to a certain number of words (not counting tags and comments). Closes opened tags if they were correctly closed in the given html. Takes an optional argument of what should be used to notify that the string has been truncated, defaulting to ellipsis (...).

Newlines in the HTML are preserved. From the django framework.

pym.lib.validate_name(s)¶
pym.lib.RE_INVALID_FS_CHARS = re.compile('[\\x00-\\x1f\\x7f]+')¶

Invalid characters for a filename in OS filesystem, e.g. ext3.

  • NULL byte
  • Control characters 0x01..0x1f (01..31)
  • Escape Character 0x7f (127)
pym.lib.RE_NAME_CHARS = re.compile('^[-a-zA-Z0-9_][-a-zA-Z0-9_.]*$')¶

Valid characters for a filename. Filename is disallowed to start with a dot.
